newsitem.title: USA: Dow ends lower as tobacco shares again hammered.
newsitem.headline: Dow ends lower as tobacco shares again hammered.

text.p: U.S. blue chips snapped a three-day winning streak as Philip Morris and other tobacco stocks bowed under the weight of mounting industry lawsuits and signs of increased government oversight.
"Philip Morris is accounting for the cloud over the market," said Alan Ackerman, a Fahnestock market strategist.
The Dow industrials lost 31 to about 5690 after climbing 56 points over the past three sessions. Philip Morris lost 3-7/8 to 87-5/8, accounting for more than one-third of the Dow's losses.

Tobacco shares were already under pressure Wednesday by news that Michigan became the 13th state to sue the industry and as a key cigarette trial in Indianapolis was nearing an end. But a blue-chip rally from lows was nipped by late news that President Clinton plans on Friday to accept an FDA recommendation that tobacco be regulated as a drug.

"It seems to be one problem after another. It's a negative for Philip Morris and other tobacco stocks but I don't think it'll affect the rest of the market," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany Corp.
Ackerman said, "There's no telling how investors will value tobacco stocks from here on in. It's certainly not an area where an investor can jump in."
Investors are still mindful of the stiff selling in tobacco shares in the wake of an August 8 Florida jury ruling against the industry in a suit filed by a smoker.
Among tobacco shares, RJR Nabisco, parent of R.J. Reynolds Tobacco, lost 1-1/8 to 25-3/8, smokeless tobacco maker UST Inc fell 7/8 to 30-7/8 and Loews lost 1-1/4 to 76-5/8.
Meanwhile, late aggressive buying in technology issues spurred the Nasdaq Composite to rise two to 1127.
IBM rose 1-7/8 to 112-3/8, Intel added 3/4 to 80-1/4 and Cisco Systems added 1-1/4 to 56-1/4.
But the broader market remained weaker with losers beating gainers 6-5 on moderate NYSE volume of about 346 million.

"We're operating in a vaccuum. The only thing to stimulate stocks is bonds," said Larry Wachtel, a Prudential Securities market analyst. "There's not much volume, not many players and not much conviction."
The long bond slumped 1/2 point to yield 6.84 percent.
"We had basic profit-taking in stocks," said Peter Cardillo, director of research of Westfalia Investments.
But tobacco stocks nonetheless remained a focus, with players awaiting the outcome of the Marion County Superior Court case. The jury is expected to get the case Thursday.
"If they win, tobacco stocks will be saved. If not, tobacco stocks will get another whacking," Wachtel said.
Among individual stocks, Newbridge Networks jumped 11 to 59-3/8 in NYSE trading after the company laid to rest lingering investor fears with a solid first-quarter report.
J.P. Morgan upgraded Newbridge to buy from market performer and Cowen raised 1997 and 1998 earnings estimates.
Jenny Craig slumped 5-7/8 to 11-3/8.
After Tuesday's close, the company blamed new weight-loss drugs for recent soft demand during the normally slow summer period. CS First Boston cut the stock to hold from buy.
Rexene Corp fell 2-1/4 to 10-1/2 after privately held Huntsman Corp announced late Tuesday that it was withdrawing its unsolicited $460 million bid for the chemical firm.
Oracle lost 1-1/8 to 37-7/8. Goldman Sachs downgraded the stock to its recommended list due to its sharp price appreciation. The stock had been on Goldman's priority list for about one year.
Diana Corp climbed 8-7/8 to 30-1/8. The stock has been volatile, swept higher and knocked lower as an Internet play. Diana said it knew of no reason for Wednesday's stock rise.
Genesis Health rose 2-1/8 to 24-1/2. Merrill Lynch named Genesis its Focus One stock of the week.
The Nasdaq Composite rose 2.17 to 1126.84.
The S&P 500 index fell 0.62 to 665.07.
(Figures official as of 1645 EDT/2045 GMT)
-- Wall Street desk, 212 859 1721
